Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Policing Immigrants: Immigration and Local Governance

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Although the federal government has the exclusive authority to regulate migration in the United States, increasingly, cities are creating immigration policies aimed at expelling immigrants from their localities. This project focuses on how local bureaucracies implement immigration control, using Nashville, Tennessee, and its application of 287(g) as a case study. Authorized under Section 287(g) of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Responsibility Act, 287(g) allows local law enforcement officials to check immigrants' citizenship status and, if necessary, process them for deportation. In Nashville, both the Police and Sheriff's Departments are implicated in 287(g) implementation; police officers arrest people who are subsequently screened for immigration violations by Sheriff's deputies.

The research strategy for this project involves interviews with stake-holders in the 287(g) policy arena and ethnographic observations, including police ride-alongs. Interviews with administrators and employees in local law enforcement agencies are conducted to understand employee preferences with respect to 287(g) implementation, as well as bureaucratic practices, professional identity, professional norms, and perceived levels of external pressure. Interviews with immigrant advocates uncover how, or if, their organizations pressure local agencies for non-implementation, and get at the effects of 287(g) on the local immigrant population.

Drawing from theories of bureaucracy suggesting that people on the front lines of policy implementation make policy through their actions, this project examines how 287(g) implementation depends on the preferences of actors in the policy arena, and the institutional characteristics of local law enforcement agencies. This research is important because it challenges assumptions about the growing trend toward local immigration enforcement by demonstrating the on-the-ground rules of immigration policing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Although the federal government has the exclusive authority to regulate migration in the United States, increasingly, cities are creating immigration policies aimed at expelling immigrants from their localities. For example, the 287(g) program, authorized under Section 287(g) of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act, allows local law enforcement officials to check immigrants’ legal status and process unauthorized immigrants for removal. This project provides an in-depth examination of the 287(g) program in Davidson County, Tennessee, focusing on how local bureaucracies implement immigration control. Specifically, police officers arrest people who are subsequently screened for immigration violations by Sheriff’s deputies through the 287(g) program if they are foreign born.

The research strategy for this project involved interviews and ethnographic observations, including police ride-alongs.  Interviews with administrators and employees in local law enforcement agencies were conducted to understand employee preferences with respect to 287(g) implementation, as well as bureaucratic practices, professional identity, professional norms, and perceived levels of external pressure. Interviews with immigrant advocates uncovered how, or if, their organizations pressure local agencies for non-implementation, as well as the effects of 287(g) on the immigrant population. The NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant funded six months of fieldwork in Davidson County and transcription services for selected in-depth interviews.    

In Davidson County, all foreign born arrestees are screened for their immigration status; consequently, 287(g) outcomes depend on who police officers arrest. Data from this study reveals three key findings. First, patrol officers feel pressure from upper level administration to make traffic stops, putting them in contact with unauthorized immigrants who are vulnerable to arrest because they do not have legal permission to drive or state issued identification cards. Second, because deputized immigration officers do not decide who to screen for immigration status or who to place in removal proceedings, the 287(g) program operates as a dragnet and results in the removal of thousands of immigrants arrested for misdemeanor violations. Third, the 287(g) program provides political benefits for both local and federal agencies. At the local level, the Sheriff’s office proves it is “doing something” about dangerous criminal aliens and at the federal level, 287(g) provides another way to funnel removable immigrants into detention.

These findings contribute to our understandings of administrative discretion and the ways it is deployed in various agencies. Moreover, this research has important implications for an emerging immigration enforcement strategy called Secure Communities, which seeks to identify removable immigrants in every jail across the country by running every arrestee’s name and fingerprint information through a federal database. Outcomes for this jail-based immigration screening program will depend on the norms and behaviors of police officers who decide when to arrest immigrants and take them to jail. As these arrests will increasingly trigger deportation, immigrant communities will undoubtedly be more distrustful of their local police force. Thus, to the extent that people believe that immigrants’ fear of the police is dangerous for their communities or that minor violations should not trigger removal, organizations can direct their resources at improving police-immigrant relations thereby decreasing the likelihood that officers make custodial arrests based on misunderstandings or minor violations.
